name: Andromeda
desc: The Princess Andromeda; in Greek mythology, the daughter of Cepheus and Cassiopeia and wife of Perseus.

name: Antlia
desc: The air pump; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, originally the 'pneumatic machine'.

name: Apus
desc: The bird of paradise; a southern constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Aquarius
desc: The water bearer; in Greek mythology, Ganymede, wine-waiter to the Gods and lover of Zeus.

name: Aquila
desc: The eagle; in Greek mythology, the bird of Zeus and the retriever of his thunderbolts.

name: Ara
desc: The altar; in Greek mythology, used by the Gods to vow allegiance before their battle with the Titans.

name: Aries
desc: The ram; in Greek mythology, the animal whose golden fleece was recovered by Jason and the Argonauts.

name: Auriga
desc: The charioteer; in Greek mythology, Erichthonius, son of Vulcan, the first person to attach four horses to a chariot.

name: Bootes
desc: The herdsman; in Greek mythology, Arcas, son of Zeus by Callisto.

name: Caelum
desc: The chisel; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Camelopardalis
desc: The giraffe; a large but faint northern constellation introduced by Plancius in 1612.

name: Cancer
desc: The crab; in Greek mythology, a crab which bit Hercules's foot.

name: Canes Venatici
desc: The hunting dogs; introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, and said to be held by the herdsman Bootes.

name: Canis Major
desc: The greater dog; in Greek mythology, a hunting dog belonging to Orion, depicted pursuing the hare Lepus.

name: Canis Minor
desc: The lesser dog; in Greek mythology, a hunting dog belonging to Orion, depicted pursuing the hare Lepus.

name: Capricornus
desc: The sea goat; associated with Pan in Greek mythology, god of the countryside.

name: Carina
desc: The keel; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.

name: Cassiopeia
desc: Queen Cassiopeia; in Greek mythology, wife of Cepheus and mother of Andromeda.

name: Centaurus
desc: The Centaur: half man and half horse; in Greek mythology, the wise centaur Chiron.

name: Cepheus
desc: King Cepheus of Ethiopeia; in Greek mythology, the king of Ethiopia, descended from Zeus and Io.

name: Cetus
desc: The sea monster, which in Greek mythology attacked Cepheus's territory and Andromeda, but which was slain by Perseus.

name: Chamaeleon
desc: The chameleon; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Circinus
desc: The pair of dividing compasses; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Columba
desc: The dove; introduced by Plancius in 1592. In Biblical history, said to be the dove of Noah.

name: Coma Berenices
desc: The hair of Queen Berenice of Egypt; introduced as a constellation by Vopel in 1536.

name: Corona Australis
desc: The southern crown, lying at the feet of Sagittarius, and known to the Greeks as a wreath.

name: Corona Borealis
desc: The northern crown; in Greek mythology, worn by the Princess Ariadne on her wedding day.

name: Corvus
desc: The crow; in Greek mythology, sent by Apollo in search of water.

name: Crater
desc: The cup; in Greek mythology, clutched by the crow Crater in its search for water.

name: Crux
desc: The southern cross; introduced as a constellation by Plancius in 1598.

name: Cygnus
desc: The swan; in Greek mythology, Zeus in disguise.

name: Delphinus
desc: The dolphin; in Greek mythology, the messenger of Poseidon.

name: Dorado
desc: The goldfish; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Draco
desc: The dragon; in Greek mythology, Ladon, guard of the tree on which golden apples grew, slain by Hercules.

name: Equuleus
desc: The little horse; a tiny yet ancient constellation with no mythological association.

name: Eridanus
desc: The mythical river Eridanus; associated variously with the Nile or Po.

name: Fornax
desc: The furnace; originally a chemist's distillation furnace, introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Gemini
desc: The mythical twins Castor and Pollux.

name: Grus
desc: The crane; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Hercules
desc: Hercules; a large yet dark constellation representing the greatest hero of Greek mythology.

name: Horologium
desc: The pendulum clock; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Hydra
desc: The multi-headed water snake, slain by Hercules in Greek mythology.

name: Hydrus
desc: The lesser water snake; introduced as a constellation by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Indus
desc: The Indian; introduced as a constellation by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Lacerta
desc: The lizard; introduced as a constellation by Johannes Hevelius in 1690.

name: Leo
desc: The lion of Nemea; in Greek mythology, a monster slain by Hercules.

name: Leo Minor
desc: The lion cub; introduced as a constellation by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.

name: Lepus
desc: The hare; often depicted being chased by Orion and his two dogs.

name: Libra
desc: The balance; a zodiacal constellation introduced by the Romans.

name: Lupus
desc: The wolf; an ancient constellation, but without mythological association.

name: Lynx
desc: The lynx; a faint constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.

name: Lyra
desc: The lyre; often said to be played by Orpheus, the greatest musician of his age.

name: Mensa
desc: Table Mountain, South Africa; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, celebrating his southern-hemisphere observing site.

name: Microscopium
desc: The microscope; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Monoceros
desc: The unicorn; a constellation introduced by Plancius in 1612.

name: Musca
desc: The fly; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Norma
desc: The set square; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Octans
desc: The octant, a navigational instrument invented in the 1730s. A modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Ophiuchus
desc: The serpent bearer; in Greek mythology, Asclepius, the god of medicine, depicted in the sky holding the snake Serpens.

name: Orion
desc: The hunter; associated in Greek mythology with a son of Poseidon, but associated by the Sumerians with their great hero Gilgamesh.

name: Pavo
desc: The peacock; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Pegasus
desc: The winged horse; in Greek mythology, used by Zeus to carry thunder and lightning.

name: Perseus
desc: Perseus; in Greek mythology, the husband of Andromeda, also known for slaying Medusa the Gorgon.

name: Phoenix
desc: The phoenix; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Pictor
desc: The painter's easel; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Pisces
desc: Two fishes, swimming in opposite directions with their tails connected by a cord.

name: Piscis Austrinus
desc: The southern fish; the parent of the two fish depicted by Pisces.

name: Puppis
desc: The poop deck of the Argo Navis; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.

name: Pyxis
desc: The compass; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Reticulum
desc: The net; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, commemorating the cross-hair in his telescope.

name: Sagitta
desc: The arrow; in Greek mythology, perhaps the arrow that Apollo used to kill the Cyclopes.

name: Sagittarius
desc: The archer; usually drawn as a centaur – half man, half horse

name: Scorpius
desc: The scorpion; said to have stung the hunter Orion to death in Greek mythology.

name: Sculptor
desc: The sculptor – originally, the sculptor's studio; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Scutum
desc: The shield; a constellation honouring King John III Sobieski of Poland – the only politically inspired constellation still in use.

name: Serpens
desc: The serpent's head; held by Ophiuchus and part of the same constellation as Serpens Cauda.

name: Serpens Cauda
desc: The serpent's tail; held by Ophiuchus and part of the same constellation as Serpens Caput.

name: Sextans
desc: The sextant; a constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, celebrating an instrument used to measure star positions.

name: Taurus
desc: The bull; said by the Sumerians to be charging at Orion the hunter, but in Greek mythology said to be Zeus in disguise.

name: Telescopium
desc: The telescope; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

name: Triangulum
desc: The triangle; appearing similar to a capital delta in the Greek alphabet.

name: Triangulum Australe
desc: The southern triangle; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Tucana
desc: The toucan; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

name: Ursa Major
desc: The great bear, also known as the Big Dipper or the Plough. In Greek mythology, Callisto, lover of Zeus.

name: Ursa Minor
desc: The lesser bear; in Greek mythology, one of the nymphs that nursed Zeus as an infant.

name: Vela
desc: The sail; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.

name: Virgo
desc: The virgin; in Greek mythology, the goddess of justice.

name: Volans
desc: The flying fish; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598, celebrating the family Exocoetidae.

name: Vulpecula
desc: The fox; a constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.
